author: djrtwo
content: Agreed on fork choice tests, but the example given above I don't think there is a subtle "got ya" here. At slot N+2, if a proposer tried to build on the parent of what the head of the chain was at N instead of the block built at N+1, the N+2 proposer is very likely not going to be able to garner support for this fork because attestations for C1 already exist so everyone during N+2 is going to see C1 as the rightful head and keep voting on it

author: m.kalinin
content: You're right. It's supplied by XMD GHOST itself rather than by these two conditions that I was referring to. I guess those two are to prevent bouncing and racing caused by attestations coming bit by bit from the network.

author: m.kalinin
content: What is the rationale behind `1024` as `ETH1_FOLLOW_DISTANCE`? Do we have an explanation about that anywhere?

author: djrtwo
content:
A depth that is without question beyond any normal reorgs on the eth1 chain such that at serious PoW attack would be required to break the tie between eth1/eth2.

Beyond that, I'm pretty sure some (all?) eth1 clients can't even handle a reorg that deep.
